title: 104_s557
content: The Act titled "Derivatives Limitations Act of 1995" amends the Federal Deposit Insurance Act by adding a new section regarding derivative instruments. The Derivatives Limitations Act of 1995 prohibits insured depository institutions and affiliates from engaging in derivative financial instrument transactions, with exceptions for hedging transactions approved by the appropriate Federal banking agency. Insured depository institutions and their affiliates can engage in derivative financial instrument transactions if they comply with regulations set by the appropriate Federal banking agency. Additionally, insured depository institutions can participate in transactions involving de minimis interests in derivative financial instruments as defined and approved by the agency. During the 3-month period after enactment, existing interests in derivative financial instruments of insured depository institutions are protected, and their ability to acquire related interests for resolution purposes is not restricted. The appropriate Federal banking agency shall issue rules, regulations, and orders governing exceptions for derivative financial instruments, including public notice requirements and notification by affiliates that assets are not insured or guaranteed by the Federal Government. The appropriate Federal banking agency will establish rules for derivative financial instruments, including defining what constitutes a derivative financial instrument and any additional requirements deemed necessary. The term 'hedging transaction' refers to a derivative financial instrument used by institutions to reduce risks related to price changes, currency fluctuations, interest rates, and investments. The institution must clearly identify a transaction as a hedging transaction before the end of the day it was entered into, as per regulations set by the appropriate Federal banking agency. SEC. 215. DERIVATIVE INSTRUMENTS is added to Title II of the Federal Credit Union Act, allowing insured credit unions to use derivative instruments. The Federal Credit Union Act allows insured credit unions to use derivative instruments, with restrictions on derivative activities and enforcement similar to those for insured depository institutions under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. Derivative financial instruments include stocks, bonds, loan instruments, assets, interest rates, currency exchange rates, and other instruments determined by the Board. SEC. 4. BANK HOLDING COMPANIES. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to allow subsidiaries of bank holding companies to engage in derivative activities if they are separately capitalized from insured depository institutions. This amendment also applies Section 44 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to bank holding companies and the Board. The Board enforces regulations on derivative financial instruments for bank holding companies, defined as instruments derived from various assets or indexes. The term "financial instrument" is specified in this subsection.
